segment.source: This reference topic for the IT professional describes the default Active Directory security groups.
segment.target: This reference topic for the IT professional describes the default Active Directory security groups.

segment.source: There are two forms of common security principals in Active Directory: user accounts and computer accounts.
segment.target: There are two forms of common security principals in Active Directory: user accounts and computer accounts.

segment.source: These accounts represent a physical entity (a person or a computer).
segment.target: These accounts represent a physical entity (a person or a computer).

segment.source: User accounts can also be used as dedicated service accounts for some applications.
segment.target: User accounts can also be used as dedicated service accounts for some applications.

segment.source: Security groups are used to collect user accounts, computer accounts, and other groups into manageable units.
segment.target: Security groups are used to collect user accounts, computer accounts, and other groups into manageable units.

segment.source: In the Windows Server operating system, there are several built-in accounts and security groups that are preconfigured with the appropriate rights and permissions to perform specific tasks.
segment.target: In the Windows Server operating system, there are several built-in accounts and security groups that are preconfigured with the appropriate rights and permissions to perform specific tasks.

segment.source: For Active Directory, there are two types of administrative responsibilities:
segment.target: For Active Directory, there are two types of administrative responsibilities:

segment.source: Service administrators Responsible for maintaining and delivering Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS), including managing domain controllers and configuring the AD DS.
segment.target: Service administrators Responsible for maintaining and delivering Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS), including managing domain controllers and configuring the AD DS.

segment.source: Data administrators Responsible for maintaining the data that is stored in AD DS and on domain member servers and workstations.
segment.target: Data administrators Responsible for maintaining the data that is stored in AD DS and on domain member servers and workstations.

segment.source: Groups are used to collect user accounts, computer accounts, and other groups into manageable units.
segment.target: Groups are used to collect user accounts, computer accounts, and other groups into manageable units.

segment.source: Working with groups instead of with individual users helps simplify network maintenance and administration.
segment.target: Working with groups instead of with individual users helps simplify network maintenance and administration.

segment.source: There are two types of groups in Active Directory:
segment.target: There are two types of groups in Active Directory:

segment.source: Distribution groups Used to create email distribution lists.
segment.target: Distribution groups Used to create email distribution lists.

segment.source: Security groups Used to assign permissions to shared resources.
segment.target: Security groups Used to assign permissions to shared resources.

segment.source: Distribution groups can be used only with email applications (such as Exchange Server) to send email to collections of users.
segment.target: Distribution groups can be used only with email applications (such as Exchange Server) to send email to collections of users.

segment.source: Distribution groups are not security enabled, which means that they cannot be listed in discretionary access control lists (DACLs).
segment.target: Distribution groups are not security enabled, which means that they cannot be listed in discretionary access control lists (DACLs).

segment.source: Security groups can provide an efficient way to assign access to resources on your network.
segment.target: Security groups can provide an efficient way to assign access to resources on your network.

segment.source: By using security groups, you can:
segment.target: By using security groups, you can:

segment.source: Assign user rights to security groups in Active Directory.
segment.target: Assign user rights to security groups in Active Directory.

segment.source: User rights are assigned to a security group to determine what members of that group can do within the scope of a domain or forest.
segment.target: User rights are assigned to a security group to determine what members of that group can do within the scope of a domain or forest.

segment.source: User rights are automatically assigned to some security groups when Active Directory is installed to help administrators define a person’s administrative role in the domain.
segment.target: User rights are automatically assigned to some security groups when Active Directory is installed to help administrators define a person’s administrative role in the domain.

segment.source: For example, a user who is added to the Backup Operators group in Active Directory has the ability to back up and restore files and directories that are located on each domain controller in the domain.
segment.target: For example, a user who is added to the Backup Operators group in Active Directory has the ability to back up and restore files and directories that are located on each domain controller in the domain.

segment.source: This is possible because, by default, the user rights Backup files and directories and Restore files and directories are automatically assigned to the Backup Operators group.
segment.target: This is possible because, by default, the user rights Backup files and directories and Restore files and directories are automatically assigned to the Backup Operators group.

segment.source: Therefore, members of this group inherit the user rights that are assigned to that group.
segment.target: Therefore, members of this group inherit the user rights that are assigned to that group.

segment.source: You can use Group Policy to assign user rights to security groups to delegate specific tasks.
segment.target: You can use Group Policy to assign user rights to security groups to delegate specific tasks.

segment.source: For more information about using Group Policy, see User Rights Assignment.
segment.target: For more information about using Group Policy, see User Rights Assignment.

segment.source: Assign permissions to security groups for resources.
segment.target: Assign permissions to security groups for resources.

segment.source: Permissions are different than user rights.
segment.target: Permissions are different than user rights.

segment.source: Permissions are assigned to the security group for the shared resource.
segment.target: Permissions are assigned to the security group for the shared resource.

segment.source: Permissions determine who can access the resource and the level of access, such as Full Control.
segment.target: Permissions determine who can access the resource and the level of access, such as Full Control.

segment.source: Some permissions that are set on domain objects are automatically assigned to allow various levels of access to default security groups, such as the Account Operators group or the Domain Admins group.
segment.target: Some permissions that are set on domain objects are automatically assigned to allow various levels of access to default security groups, such as the Account Operators group or the Domain Admins group.

segment.source: Security groups are listed in DACLs that define permissions on resources and objects.
segment.target: Security groups are listed in DACLs that define permissions on resources and objects.

segment.source: When assigning permissions for resources (file shares, printers, and so on), administrators should assign those permissions to a security group rather than to individual users.
segment.target: When assigning permissions for resources (file shares, printers, and so on), administrators should assign those permissions to a security group rather than to individual users.

segment.source: The permissions are assigned once to the group, instead of several times to each individual user.
segment.target: The permissions are assigned once to the group, instead of several times to each individual user.

segment.source: Each account that is added to a group receives the rights that are assigned to that group in Active Directory, and the user receives the permissions that are defined for that group.
segment.target: Each account that is added to a group receives the rights that are assigned to that group in Active Directory, and the user receives the permissions that are defined for that group.

segment.source: Like distribution groups, security groups can be used as an email entity.
segment.target: Like distribution groups, security groups can be used as an email entity.

segment.source: Sending an email message to the group sends the message to all the members of the group.
segment.target: Sending an email message to the group sends the message to all the members of the group.

segment.source: Groups are characterized by a scope that identifies the extent to which the group is applied in the domain tree or forest.
segment.target: Groups are characterized by a scope that identifies the extent to which the group is applied in the domain tree or forest.

segment.source: The scope of the group defines where the group can be granted permissions.
segment.target: The scope of the group defines where the group can be granted permissions.

segment.source: The following three group scopes are defined by Active Directory:
segment.target: The following three group scopes are defined by Active Directory:

segment.source: In addition to these three scopes, the default groups in the Builtin container have a group scope of Builtin Local.
segment.target: In addition to these three scopes, the default groups in the Builtin container have a group scope of Builtin Local.

segment.source: This group scope and group type cannot be changed.
segment.target: This group scope and group type cannot be changed.

segment.source: The following table lists the three group scopes and more information about each scope for a security group.
segment.target: The following table lists the three group scopes and more information about each scope for a security group.

segment.source: Special identities are generally referred to as groups.
segment.target: Special identities are generally referred to as groups.

segment.source: Special identity groups do not have specific memberships that can be modified, but they can represent different users at different times, depending on the circumstances.
segment.target: Special identity groups do not have specific memberships that can be modified, but they can represent different users at different times, depending on the circumstances.

segment.source: Some of these groups include Creator Owner, Batch, and Authenticated User.
segment.target: Some of these groups include Creator Owner, Batch, and Authenticated User.

segment.source: For information about all the special identity groups, see Special Identities.
segment.target: For information about all the special identity groups, see Special Identities.

segment.source: Default groups, such as the Domain Admins group, are security groups that are created automatically when you create an Active Directory domain.
segment.target: Default groups, such as the Domain Admins group, are security groups that are created automatically when you create an Active Directory domain.

segment.source: You can use these predefined groups to help control access to shared resources and to delegate specific domain-wide administrative roles.
segment.target: You can use these predefined groups to help control access to shared resources and to delegate specific domain-wide administrative roles.

segment.source: Many default groups are automatically assigned a set of user rights that authorize members of the group to perform specific actions in a domain, such as logging on to a local system or backing up files and folders.
segment.target: Many default groups are automatically assigned a set of user rights that authorize members of the group to perform specific actions in a domain, such as logging on to a local system or backing up files and folders.

segment.source: For example, a member of the Backup Operators group has the right to perform backup operations for all domain controllers in the domain.
segment.target: For example, a member of the Backup Operators group has the right to perform backup operations for all domain controllers in the domain.

segment.source: When you add a user to a group, the user receives all the user rights that are assigned to the group and all the permissions that are assigned to the group for any shared resources.
segment.target: When you add a user to a group, the user receives all the user rights that are assigned to the group and all the permissions that are assigned to the group for any shared resources.

segment.source: Default groups are located in the Builtin container and in the Users container in Active Directory Users and Computers.
segment.target: Default groups are located in the Builtin container and in the Users container in Active Directory Users and Computers.

segment.source: The Builtin container includes groups that are defined with the Domain Local scope.
segment.target: The Builtin container includes groups that are defined with the Domain Local scope.

segment.source: The Users includes contains groups that are defined with Global scope and groups that are defined with Domain Local scope.
segment.target: The Users includes contains groups that are defined with Global scope and groups that are defined with Domain Local scope.

segment.source: You can move groups that are located in these containers to other groups or organizational units (OU) within the domain, but you cannot move them to other domains.
segment.target: You can move groups that are located in these containers to other groups or organizational units (OU) within the domain, but you cannot move them to other domains.

segment.source: Some of the administrative groups that are listed in this topic and all members of these groups are protected by a background process that periodically checks for and applies a specific security descriptor.
segment.target: Some of the administrative groups that are listed in this topic and all members of these groups are protected by a background process that periodically checks for and applies a specific security descriptor.

segment.source: This descriptor is a data structure that contains security information associated with a protected object.
segment.target: This descriptor is a data structure that contains security information associated with a protected object.

segment.source: This process ensures that any successful unauthorized attempt to modify the security descriptor on one of the administrative accounts or groups will be overwritten with the protected settings.
segment.target: This process ensures that any successful unauthorized attempt to modify the security descriptor on one of the administrative accounts or groups will be overwritten with the protected settings.

segment.source: The security descriptor is present on the AdminSDHolder object.
segment.target: The security descriptor is present on the AdminSDHolder object.

segment.source: This means that if you want to modify the permissions on one of the service administrator groups or on any of its member accounts, you must modify the security descriptor on the AdminSDHolder object so that it will be applied consistently.
segment.target: This means that if you want to modify the permissions on one of the service administrator groups or on any of its member accounts, you must modify the security descriptor on the AdminSDHolder object so that it will be applied consistently.

segment.source: Be careful when you make these modifications because you are also changing the default settings that will be applied to all of your protected administrative accounts.
segment.target: Be careful when you make these modifications because you are also changing the default settings that will be applied to all of your protected administrative accounts.

segment.source: The Account Operators group grants limited account creation privileges to a user.
segment.target: The Account Operators group grants limited account creation privileges to a user.

segment.source: Members of this group can create and modify most types of accounts, including those of users, local groups, and global groups, and members can log in locally to domain controllers.
segment.target: Members of this group can create and modify most types of accounts, including those of users, local groups, and global groups, and members can log in locally to domain controllers.

segment.source: Members of the Account Operators group cannot manage the Administrator user account, the user accounts of administrators, or the Administrators, Server Operators, Account Operators, Backup Operators, or Print Operators groups.
segment.target: Members of the Account Operators group cannot manage the Administrator user account, the user accounts of administrators, or the Administrators, Server Operators, Account Operators, Backup Operators, or Print Operators groups.

segment.source: Members of the DnsUpdateProxy group are DNS clients.
segment.target: Members of the DnsUpdateProxy group are DNS clients.

segment.source: They are permitted to perform dynamic updates on behalf of other clients (such as DHCP servers).
segment.target: They are permitted to perform dynamic updates on behalf of other clients (such as DHCP servers).

segment.source: A DNS server can develop stale resource records when a DHCP server is configured to dynamically register host (A) and pointer (PTR) resource records on behalf of DHCP clients by using dynamic update.
segment.target: A DNS server can develop stale resource records when a DHCP server is configured to dynamically register host (A) and pointer (PTR) resource records on behalf of DHCP clients by using dynamic update.

segment.source: Adding clients to this security group mitigates this scenario.
segment.target: Adding clients to this security group mitigates this scenario.

segment.source: However, to protect against unsecured records or to permit members of the DnsUpdateProxy group to register records in zones that allow only secured dynamic updates, you must create a dedicated user account and configure DHCP servers to perform DNS dynamic updates by using the credentials of this account (user name, password, and domain).
segment.target: However, to protect against unsecured records or to permit members of the DnsUpdateProxy group to register records in zones that allow only secured dynamic updates, you must create a dedicated user account and configure DHCP servers to perform DNS dynamic updates by using the credentials of this account (user name, password, and domain).

segment.source: Multiple DHCP servers can use the credentials of one dedicated user account.
segment.target: Multiple DHCP servers can use the credentials of one dedicated user account.

segment.source: For information, see DNS Record Ownership and the DnsUpdateProxy Group.
segment.target: For information, see DNS Record Ownership and the DnsUpdateProxy Group.

segment.source: Members of this group are Read-Only Domain Controllers in the enterprise.
segment.target: Members of this group are Read-Only Domain Controllers in the enterprise.

segment.source: Except for account passwords, a Read-only domain controller holds all the Active Directory objects and attributes that a writable domain controller holds.
segment.target: Except for account passwords, a Read-only domain controller holds all the Active Directory objects and attributes that a writable domain controller holds.

segment.source: However, changes cannot be made to the database that is stored on the Read-only domain controller.
segment.target: However, changes cannot be made to the database that is stored on the Read-only domain controller.

segment.source: Changes must be made on a writable domain controller and then replicated to the Read-only domain controller.
segment.target: Changes must be made on a writable domain controller and then replicated to the Read-only domain controller.

segment.source: Read-only domain controllers address some of the issues that are commonly found in branch offices.
segment.target: Read-only domain controllers address some of the issues that are commonly found in branch offices.

segment.source: These locations might not have a domain controller.
segment.target: These locations might not have a domain controller.

segment.source: Or, they might have a writable domain controller, but not the physical security, network bandwidth, or local expertise to support it.

segment.source: Active Directory provides security across multiple domains or forests through domain and forest trust relationships.

segment.source: Before authentication can occur across trusts, Windows must determine whether the domain being requested by a user, computer, or service has a trust relationship with the logon domain of the requesting account.
segment.target: Before authentication can occur across trusts, Windows must determine whether the domain being requested by a user, computer, or service has a trust relationship with the logon domain of the requesting account.

segment.source: To make this determination, the Windows security system computes a trust path between the domain controller for the server that receives the request and a domain controller in the domain of the requesting account.
segment.target: To make this determination, the Windows security system computes a trust path between the domain controller for the server that receives the request and a domain controller in the domain of the requesting account.

segment.source: Members of the Protected Users group are afforded additional protection against the compromise of credentials during authentication processes.
segment.target: Members of the Protected Users group are afforded additional protection against the compromise of credentials during authentication processes.

segment.source: This security group is designed as part of a strategy to effectively protect and manage credentials within the enterprise.
segment.target: This security group is designed as part of a strategy to effectively protect and manage credentials within the enterprise.

segment.source: Members of this group automatically have non-configurable protection applied to their accounts.
segment.target: Members of this group automatically have non-configurable protection applied to their accounts.

segment.source: Membership in the Protected Users group is meant to be restrictive and proactively secure by default.
segment.target: Membership in the Protected Users group is meant to be restrictive and proactively secure by default.

segment.source: The only method to modify the protection for an account is to remove the account from the security group.
segment.target: The only method to modify the protection for an account is to remove the account from the security group.

segment.source: This domain-related, global group triggers non-configurable protection on devices and host computers running Windows Server 2012 R2 and Windows 8.1, and on domain controllers in domains with a primary domain controller running Windows Server 2012 R2.
segment.target: This domain-related, global group triggers non-configurable protection on devices and host computers running Windows Server 2012 R2 and Windows 8.1, and on domain controllers in domains with a primary domain controller running Windows Server 2012 R2.

segment.source: This greatly reduces the memory footprint of credentials when users sign in to computers on the network from a non-compromised computer.
segment.target: This greatly reduces the memory footprint of credentials when users sign in to computers on the network from a non-compromised computer.

segment.source: Depending on the account’s domain functional level, members of the Protected Users group are further protected due to behavior changes in the authentication methods that are supported in Windows.
segment.target: Depending on the account’s domain functional level, members of the Protected Users group are further protected due to behavior changes in the authentication methods that are supported in Windows.

segment.source: Members of the Protected Users group cannot authenticate by using the following Security Support Providers (SSPs): NTLM, Digest Authentication, or CredSSP.
segment.target: Members of the Protected Users group cannot authenticate by using the following Security Support Providers (SSPs): NTLM, Digest Authentication, or CredSSP.

segment.source: Passwords are not cached on a device running Windows 8.1, so the device fails to authenticate to a domain when the account is a member of the Protected User group.
segment.target: Passwords are not cached on a device running Windows 8.1, so the device fails to authenticate to a domain when the account is a member of the Protected User group.

segment.source: The Kerberos protocol will not use the weaker DES or RC4 encryption types in the preauthentication process.
segment.target: The Kerberos protocol will not use the weaker DES or RC4 encryption types in the preauthentication process.

segment.source: This means that the domain must be configured to support at least the AES cipher suite.
segment.target: This means that the domain must be configured to support at least the AES cipher suite.

segment.source: The user’s account cannot be delegated with Kerberos constrained or unconstrained delegation.
segment.target: The user’s account cannot be delegated with Kerberos constrained or unconstrained delegation.

segment.source: This means that former connections to other systems may fail if the user is a member of the Protected Users group.
segment.target: This means that former connections to other systems may fail if the user is a member of the Protected Users group.

segment.source: The default Kerberos ticket-granting tickets (TGTs) lifetime setting of four hours is configurable by using Authentication Policies and Silos, which can be accessed through the Active Directory Administrative Center.
segment.target: The default Kerberos ticket-granting tickets (TGTs) lifetime setting of four hours is configurable by using Authentication Policies and Silos, which can be accessed through the Active Directory Administrative Center.

segment.source: This means that when four hours has passed, the user must authenticate again.
segment.target: This means that when four hours has passed, the user must authenticate again.

segment.source: This group is comprised of the Read-only domain controllers in the domain.
segment.target: This group is comprised of the Read-only domain controllers in the domain.

segment.source: A Read-only domain controller makes it possible for organizations to easily deploy a domain controller in scenarios where physical security cannot be guaranteed, such as branch office locations, or in scenarios where local storage of all domain passwords is considered a primary threat, such as in an extranet or in an application-facing role.
segment.target: A Read-only domain controller makes it possible for organizations to easily deploy a domain controller in scenarios where physical security cannot be guaranteed, such as branch office locations, or in scenarios where local storage of all domain passwords is considered a primary threat, such as in an extranet or in an application-facing role.

segment.source: Because administration of a Read-only domain controller can be delegated to a domain user or security group, an Read-only domain controller is well suited for a site that should not have a user who is a member of the Domain Admins group.
segment.target: Because administration of a Read-only domain controller can be delegated to a domain user or security group, an Read-only domain controller is well suited for a site that should not have a user who is a member of the Domain Admins group.

segment.source: Computers that are members of the Replicator group support file replication in a domain.
segment.target: Computers that are members of the Replicator group support file replication in a domain.

segment.source: Windows Server operating systems use the File Replication service (FRS) to replicate system policies and logon scripts stored in the System Volume (SYSVOL).
segment.target: Windows Server operating systems use the File Replication service (FRS) to replicate system policies and logon scripts stored in the System Volume (SYSVOL).

segment.source: Each domain controller keeps a copy of SYSVOL for network clients to access.
segment.target: Each domain controller keeps a copy of SYSVOL for network clients to access.

segment.source: FRS can also replicate data for the Distributed File System (DFS), synchronizing the content of each member in a replica set as defined by DFS.
segment.target: FRS can also replicate data for the Distributed File System (DFS), synchronizing the content of each member in a replica set as defined by DFS.

segment.source: FRS can copy and maintain shared files and folders on multiple servers simultaneously.
segment.target: FRS can copy and maintain shared files and folders on multiple servers simultaneously.

segment.source: When changes occur, content is synchronized immediately within sites and by a schedule between sites.
segment.target: When changes occur, content is synchronized immediately within sites and by a schedule between sites.

segment.source: In Windows Server 2008 R2, FRS cannot be used for replicating DFS folders or custom (non-SYSVOL) data.
segment.target: In Windows Server 2008 R2, FRS cannot be used for replicating DFS folders or custom (non-SYSVOL) data.

segment.source: A Windows Server 2008 R2 domain controller can still use FRS to replicate the contents of a SYSVOL shared resource in a domain that uses FRS for replicating the SYSVOL shared resource between domain controllers.
segment.target: A Windows Server 2008 R2 domain controller can still use FRS to replicate the contents of a SYSVOL shared resource in a domain that uses FRS for replicating the SYSVOL shared resource between domain controllers.

segment.source: However, Windows Server 2008 R2 servers cannot use FRS to replicate the contents of any replica set apart from the SYSVOL shared resource.
segment.target: However, Windows Server 2008 R2 servers cannot use FRS to replicate the contents of any replica set apart from the SYSVOL shared resource.

segment.source: The DFS Replication service is a replacement for FRS, and it can be used to replicate the contents of a SYSVOL shared resource, DFS folders, and other custom (non-SYSVOL) data.
segment.target: The DFS Replication service is a replacement for FRS, and it can be used to replicate the contents of a SYSVOL shared resource, DFS folders, and other custom (non-SYSVOL) data.

segment.source: You should migrate all non-SYSVOL FRS replica sets to DFS Replication.
segment.target: You should migrate all non-SYSVOL FRS replica sets to DFS Replication.

segment.source: For more information, see File Replication Service (FRS) Is Deprecated in Windows Server 2008 R2 (Windows).
segment.target: For more information, see File Replication Service (FRS) Is Deprecated in Windows Server 2008 R2 (Windows).

segment.source: The group is authorized to make schema changes in Active Directory.
segment.target: The group is authorized to make schema changes in Active Directory.

segment.source: By default, the only member of the group is the Administrator account for the forest root domain.
segment.target: By default, the only member of the group is the Administrator account for the forest root domain.

segment.source: This group has full administrative access to the schema.
segment.target: This group has full administrative access to the schema.

segment.source: The membership of this group can be modified by any of the service administrator groups in the root domain.
segment.target: The membership of this group can be modified by any of the service administrator groups in the root domain.

segment.source: This is considered a service administrator account because its members can modify the schema, which governs the structure and content of the entire directory.
segment.target: This is considered a service administrator account because its members can modify the schema, which governs the structure and content of the entire directory.

segment.source: For more information, see What Is the Active Directory Schema?: Active Directory.
segment.target: For more information, see What Is the Active Directory Schema?: Active Directory.

segment.source: The Schema Admins group applies to versions of the Windows Server operating system listed in the Active Directory Default Security Groups table.
segment.target: The Schema Admins group applies to versions of the Windows Server operating system listed in the Active Directory Default Security Groups table.

segment.source: Members in the Server Operators group can administer domain servers.
segment.target: Members in the Server Operators group can administer domain servers.

segment.source: This group exists only on domain controllers.
segment.target: This group exists only on domain controllers.

segment.source: By default, the group has no members.
segment.target: By default, the group has no members.

segment.source: Memebers of the Server Operators group can sign in to a server interactively, create and delete network shared resources, start and stop services, back up and restore files, format the hard disk drive of the computer, and shut down the computer.
segment.target: Memebers of the Server Operators group can sign in to a server interactively, create and delete network shared resources, start and stop services, back up and restore files, format the hard disk drive of the computer, and shut down the computer.

segment.source: This group cannot be renamed, deleted, or moved.
segment.target: This group cannot be renamed, deleted, or moved.

segment.source: By default, this built-in group has no members, and it has access to server configuration options on domain controllers.
segment.target: By default, this built-in group has no members, and it has access to server configuration options on domain controllers.

segment.source: Its membership is controlled by the service administrator groups, Administrators and Domain Admins, in the domain, and the Enterprise Admins group.
segment.target: Its membership is controlled by the service administrator groups, Administrators and Domain Admins, in the domain, and the Enterprise Admins group.

segment.source: Members in this group cannot change any administrative group memberships.
segment.target: Members in this group cannot change any administrative group memberships.

segment.source: This is considered a service administrator account because its members have physical access to domain controllers, they can perform maintenance tasks (such as backup and restore), and they have the ability to change binaries that are installed on the domain controllers.
segment.target: This is considered a service administrator account because its members have physical access to domain controllers, they can perform maintenance tasks (such as backup and restore), and they have the ability to change binaries that are installed on the domain controllers.

segment.source: Members of the Terminal Server License Servers group can update user accounts in Active Directory with information about license issuance.
segment.target: Members of the Terminal Server License Servers group can update user accounts in Active Directory with information about license issuance.

segment.source: This is used to track and report TS Per User CAL usage.
segment.target: This is used to track and report TS Per User CAL usage.

segment.source: A TS Per User CAL gives one user the right to access a Terminal Server from an unlimited number of client computers or devices.
segment.target: A TS Per User CAL gives one user the right to access a Terminal Server from an unlimited number of client computers or devices.

segment.source: This group appears as a SID until the domain controller is made the primary domain controller and it holds the operations master role (also known as flexible single master operations or FSMO).
segment.target: This group appears as a SID until the domain controller is made the primary domain controller and it holds the operations master role (also known as flexible single master operations or FSMO).

segment.source: The Terminal Server License Servers group applies to versions of the Windows Server operating system listed in the Active Directory Default Security Groups table.

segment.source: Members of the Users group are prevented from making accidental or intentional system-wide changes, and they can run most applications.
segment.target: Members of the Users group are prevented from making accidental or intentional system-wide changes, and they can run most applications.

segment.source: After the initial installation of the operating system, the only member is the Authenticated Users group.
segment.target: After the initial installation of the operating system, the only member is the Authenticated Users group.

segment.source: When a computer joins a domain, the Domain Users group is added to the Users group on the computer.
segment.target: When a computer joins a domain, the Domain Users group is added to the Users group on the computer.

segment.source: Users can perform tasks such as running applications, using local and network printers, shutting down the computer, and locking the computer.
segment.target: Users can perform tasks such as running applications, using local and network printers, shutting down the computer, and locking the computer.

segment.source: Users can install applications that only they are allowed to use if the installation program of the application supports per-user installation.
segment.target: Users can install applications that only they are allowed to use if the installation program of the application supports per-user installation.

segment.source: This group cannot be renamed, deleted, or moved.
segment.target: This group cannot be renamed, deleted, or moved.

segment.source: The Users group applies to versions of the Windows Server operating system listed in the Active Directory Default Security Groups table.
segment.target: The Users group applies to versions of the Windows Server operating system listed in the Active Directory Default Security Groups table.

segment.target: Members of this group have access to the computed token GroupsGlobalAndUniversal attribute on User objects.

segment.source: Some applications have features that read the token-groups-global-and-universal (TGGAU) attribute on user account objects or on computer account objects in Active Directory Domain Services.
segment.target: Some applications have features that read the token-groups-global-and-universal (TGGAU) attribute on user account objects or on computer account objects in Active Directory Domain Services.

segment.source: Some Win32 functions make it easier to read the TGGAU attribute.
segment.target: Some Win32 functions make it easier to read the TGGAU attribute.

segment.source: Applications that read this attribute or that call an API (referred to as a function) that reads this attribute do not succeed if the calling security context does not have access to the attribute.
segment.target: Applications that read this attribute or that call an API (referred to as a function) that reads this attribute do not succeed if the calling security context does not have access to the attribute.

segment.source: In Windows 8 and in Windows Server 2012, a Share tab was added to the Advanced Security Settings user interface.
segment.target: In Windows 8 and in Windows Server 2012, a Share tab was added to the Advanced Security Settings user interface.

segment.source: This tab displays the security properties of a remote file share.
segment.target: This tab displays the security properties of a remote file share.

segment.source: To view this information, you must have the following permissions and memberships, as appropriate for the version of Windows Server that the file server is running.
segment.target: To view this information, you must have the following permissions and memberships, as appropriate for the version of Windows Server that the file server is running.

segment.source: The WinRMRemoteWMIUsers group applies to versions of the Windows Server operating system listed in the Active Directory Default Security Groups table.
segment.target: The WinRMRemoteWMIUsers group applies to versions of the Windows Server operating system listed in the Active Directory Default Security Groups table.

segment.source: If the file share is hosted on a server that is running a supported version of the operating system:
segment.target: If the file share is hosted on a server that is running a supported version of the operating system:

segment.source: You must be a member of the WinRMRemoteWMIUsers group or the BUILTINAdministrators group.
segment.target: You must be a member of the WinRMRemoteWMIUsers group or the BUILTINAdministrators group.

segment.source: You must have Read permissions to the file share.
segment.target: You must have Read permissions to the file share.

segment.source: If the file share is hosted on a server that is running a version of Windows Server that is earlier than Windows Server 2012:
segment.target: If the file share is hosted on a server that is running a version of Windows Server that is earlier than Windows Server 2012:

segment.source: You must be a member of the BUILTINAdministrators group.
segment.target: You must be a member of the BUILTINAdministrators group.

segment.source: You must have Read permissions to the file share.
segment.target: You must have Read permissions to the file share.

segment.source: In Windows Server 2012, the Access Denied Assistance functionality adds the Authenticated Users group to the local WinRMRemoteWMIUsers group.
segment.target: In Windows Server 2012, the Access Denied Assistance functionality adds the Authenticated Users group to the local WinRMRemoteWMIUsers group.

segment.source: Therefore, when the Access Denied Assistance functionality is enabled, all authenticated users who have Read permissions to the file share can view the file share permissions.
segment.target: Therefore, when the Access Denied Assistance functionality is enabled, all authenticated users who have Read permissions to the file share can view the file share permissions.

segment.source: The WinRMRemoteWMIUsers group allows running Windows PowerShell commands remotely whereas the Remote Management Users group is generally used to allow users to manage servers by using the Server Manager console.
segment.target: The WinRMRemoteWMIUsers group allows running Windows PowerShell commands remotely whereas the Remote Management Users group is generally used to allow users to manage servers by using the Server Manager console.

segment.target: This security group was introduced in Windows Server 2012, and it has not changed in subsequent versions.
